review_data.review_title: Tasty new Indian restaurant in town
review_data.review: I decided to visit based on the other positive reviews and to check out the new Indian restaurant in town. I am a big fan of paneer dishes. I ordered the paneer tikka masala which was delicious and they were generous with the paneer which I appreciated. The mango lassi was also very tasty. Pricing is similar to other Indian restaurants in town but I would say Rasoi Ghar is one of the better Indian restaurants that I’ve tried in Siem Reap and I’ve tried a fair few.

user_data.user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;Luxury Traveler

review_data.review_title: Fab cocktails in a nice garden setting
review_data.review: The cocktails at Wild are really fab. They don’t do dinner as such but have many different types of spring rolls. So, it’s like tapas. We ordered 5 lots of different spring rolls between the 2 of us and found that to be enough for dinner. We also tried 3 different cocktails, all of which were good. The garden setting is really lovely and I can’t wait to visit again.

review_data.review_title: Mostly good but room for improvement
review_data.review: I visited twice in December, once by myself for lunch and again for lunch with hubby.  The first time I visited I had to go to the counter to ask for a menu. I sat down thinking they would bring a menu but I changed tables as I was too hot where I originally sat down. I wasn’t brought a menu at either table so I thought they didn’t have table service and you had to order at the counter by the cakes. When I asked if I could see their lunch menu they said they’d bring it over. Perhaps they didn’t see me come in but my first impression wasn’t that good. I know it’s not a big thing but nevertheless it’s nice to be greeted and brought a menu within the first few mins of entering a cafe/restaurant. Perhaps it would be better just to leave the menus on the table.  On my first visit they had run out of the vegan quiche. I understand cafes run out of food but it was a little bit disappointing since it was only around 1pm which is peak lunch time. Luckily, I’m not vegan I just like to eat vegan sometimes but from memory there weren’t that many other vegan choices so this may be a problem for others.  On my 2nd visit I was able to order the vegan quiche and my husband ordered a veggie one. Unfortunately, the vegan quiche had mustard seed and I’m allergic to mustard so I had to swap with my husband. It wasn’t written on the menu so I didn’t know before ordering. It would be nice if this info was added to the menu. I took one bite before I realized. The vegan quiche was not as tasty as the veggie quiche which contains dairy so perhaps a little tweak of the recipe might be in order.  We ordered 2 coconuts and one was nice and chilled and the other one completely warm.  On the 2nd visit we were brought menus straight away but our waitress silently took our order and also didn’t say anything when she brought our bill which my husband commented on. He thought perhaps she didn’t speak English. My husband is a local so she could have used Khmer if she preferred.  I understand this is a training school cafe so I’m writing this as constructive feedback so that others can have a more seamless experience.  The points above wouldn’t stop me from visiting again but there’s room for improvement.

review_data.review_title: Not many choices for lunch but the choices they do have are tasty
review_data.review: The only choices for the mains is cold pasta. I wasn’t sure what I’d think of the mango pasta but it wasn’t too sweet and great as a main dish.

review_data.review_title: Business lunch menu is superb value for money
review_data.review: I visited Chi restaurant with my cousin and his wife for lunch. We ordered from the business lunch menu. It is extremely good value for money considering the quality of food, ambience and service.  You can get 2 courses for $12 or 3 courses for $15 including one glass of wine or a soft drink. I found out about the business lunch menu from other TA reviews.  Unfortunately, we couldn’t afford to visit Chi restaurant for tasting menus that they offer in the evening but this was perfect.  The manager Sarah even came to introduce herself during our meal.  I would definitely like to visit again with hubby.

review_data.review_title: Smooth service for the most part
review_data.review: Sala Bai is a training school so sometimes there can be a few problems. We had a problem with one of our dishes but otherwise the meal itself and the service was very good. The duty manager came to speak to us at the end of our meal to check our dining experience which I appreciated. Eating at the training restaurant allows them to continue training students and I would definitely eat there again.

Hubby and I decided to try this new cafe since I noticed it was getting a lot of good reviews. The service was good without being overbearing and the staff checked with us if the food was ok.  They have a good selection of Khmer and Western food as well as juices and coffees. 2 mains and a green juice set us back $11.50 which I think was reasonable given the portion size and quality of the food. I would like to visit again, it’s just a shame it’s not open later on in the evening.

My husband and I had dinner here 2 nights ago. The ambience and presentation of the food was nice but the colourful sauces were more for decorative purposes than for taste which was a shame. Maybe it just wasn't to our taste.  The chive dumpling dish was better but the sauce for the veggies was so spicy it was a struggle to finish the dish.

review_data.review_title: Reasonably priced food in a beautiful garden setting
review_data.review: The price of the food was reasonable considering the beautiful setting of the restaurant. $10.50 for 2 meals and a drink. We were served fairly quickly and the service was friendly. I would definitely visit again.

review_data.review_title: Need to bring ID if not staying at the hostel
review_data.review: We visited last Friday evening.  The night didn't start off well as the security guard watching the motorbikes told us we couldn't come in because my husband is Khmer.  I started to feel my blood boil but luckily another staff member came and said we could come in but we had to go talk to reception (we weren't planning on staying, we just wanted dinner and a drink)  At reception, a lady who was a bit more knowledgeable than the security guard explained that since you have to walk past all the hostel rooms (3 floors) to get to the Sky bar where the bar/restaurant is, they need to take a copy of ID cards for Khmers and a copy of the photo page in the passport for non-Khmers to know who is coming and going for the safety and security of the guests at the hostel.  Once this was explained properly in a polite manner it was not a problem. I still find it a bit strange though as I normally don't carry around my passport when going out for dinner but luckily hubby had his ID card which meant that he became a member and could bring in a guest, me. So, it all worked out ok in the end. It's just a shame that the new security guard (we were told he was new by the other member of staff) is turning locals away.  As with most things here, it is an easily solvable problem. I don't know why they can't put up a big poster saying "ID card (for Cambodians) or passport (for non-Cambodians) needed to enter the premises for the safety and security of guests and visitors. We appreciate your co-operation."  After all, they had a poster saying their restaurant was closed but still welcome to order food at the bar, so they are capable of making and putting up signs.  The food was surprisingly good for a hostel. It was No.1 on TripAdvisor about a month ago and I was curious about it so suggested to my husband that we go.  Luckily, the nice female member of staff (didn't catch her name) and the good food managed to turn the evening around but just be forewarned that if you're not a guest you'll need ID to be able to go into the bar/restaurant area.

We decided to try something different on our last trip to New York and opted for Jungsik. We opted for the signature tasting with premium wines and we were not disappointed! Each course was flavorful with premium ingredient and original presentation. Service was friendly, attentive and efficient. The wine pairing although expensive really helped bring an additional dimension to the food with the sommelier walking us through each pairing in details.  Overall we had a wonderful night at Jungsik and even though it's not as well known as some of the other high-end restaurants in New York, we highly recommend you give it a shot!

review_data.review_title: Great experience at a reasonable price
review_data.review: We made a reservation at Aspic solely based on the glowing reviews on Trip Advisor and we were not disappointed.  As others have mentioned this is a fixed menu only type of restaurants so you need to be flexible but what came out of the kitchen on the night we were there did not disappoint one bit. What was interesting is that unlike many of the other restaurants we went to during our trip to France, Aspic offered a wine pairing with the meal which was quite nice and added an extra layer to the experience.  Service was overall good but you need to go into this with the right expectation that this is a lean operation. As far as I could tell there was the chef in the kitchen and one waitress for about 12 tables. It didn't feel slow or anything but it wasn't "high touch" either.  Overall we were pleasantly surprised with the experience. When the check came in, we were even more surprised at how affordable this experience was. Given the quality and creativity, I don't think it's going to stay this way for long so you better go and enjoy it!
Couldn't get into Don Julio but no problem because wwe found this place close by. And what a find. Amazing steaks and Malbec. Will happily go back when next in BA.

The wines are also fine. But the best is the service, special from the main waiter Rui, he was so kind in explaining the food and in wine selection. We also loved his grappa choices, which was a perfect meal ending. Thanks again Rui and hope to see you again. The 2 German guys.

review_data.review: to go with them to their new favourite restaurant in Phuket ..... they explained why they 'love' this restaurant ... and they were not wrong! On arrival on a Saturday night recently, the restaurant looked very inviting ... but very busy. on being greeted [like long lost friends!] by the front of house staff ... they explained that there was a large birthday party group [which explained the 'business!'] ... suggesting we ordered before the group ... good idea. Initially, there didn't appear to be a 4 seater table available ... but a fellow guest [on his own] volunteered to give up his table. So kind .. and we settled down to peruse the large menu ... with as advertised - European favourites and authentic Thai dishes. The meal was excellent accompanied by a bottle of red .. suggested by the Manager. The service, the food and the ambience were - just as our friends had led us to believe. No wonder they are regulars ... and we will be too.

It was interesting to hear from Cecil about life in Cambodia. Anyway I digress the food and service our top notch go there and enjoy.

review_data.review: We ate here on our first night in Marrakech, the restaurant was very busy but we managed to get a table. The staff were very friendly & the food was very tasty. Just off the main square & easy to find. We have been back again as the food was one of the best meals we ate whilst in Marrakech & ordered different dishes which were equally delicious. If you are in Marrakech you should definitely visit!

Tiny place that I walked passed several times in this "industrial" street, otherwise the home of tyre sellers, watch sellers, carpet sellers and the like. There are only 24 seats, mostly on the mezzanine area. It appears basic but noticeably clean and tidy. The menu is a blend of Moroccan and international with everything from pizzas, pastas, burgers, salads, traditional Moroccan, crepes, soups. I enjoyed a really good home made courgette and vegetable soup followed by spaghetti bolognese and fruit salad and mint tea (served with complimentary Moroccan biscuits/pastries). As it got busier there was pressure on the speed of service - but I was in no hurry - but all through there was a pride and passion for what was being served and how it was presented. Very inexpensive, an extensive menu and caring service made this place instantly likeable. Good on ya Yassine!

user_data.user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;Luxury Traveler

review_data.review: Les Apotres was just around the corner from our hotel apartment and had sensational reviews. It becomes a bit cramped with so many people and tables in such a small place (reminded me in way of dining at the Golden Temple in Amritsar). The ordering process is a bit different too - you take a menu sheet and tick what you want - no traditional waiters. The owners clearly know a thing or two about hospitality as the good feeling you get here is all about the food and style. All the dishes we ate were simple, exquisite and original - great flavours.

When we visited, there were two large parties downstairs so we settled in for a wait. We were told there would be a delay in our food arriving which was fine, we had time so made the choice to stay. Had a couple of really lovely cocktails and the OH had a large beer and an aperitif. We actually received our food pretty quickly and were so glad we decided to stay and wait. I had the Caesar burger, a patty with lettuce, croutons, Parmesan and delicious Caesar dressing. Hubby had bacon, cheese, rocket and caramelised onions with his. Both were absolutely delicious. Decent portion of good fries on the side. Really reasonably priced considering what we had and the quality. This place is a little off the beaten track although still really central. But it’s not somewhere you’d necessarily walk past on a tourist route. Search it out, I heartily recommend it. One of the best burgers I’ve had for a long long time.

Live the Goulash Soup and wife love, loves the fries. Wife wants them to bring back the Minestrone Soup for next year!  Love this place!

review_data.review: This place smells so good as you walk by, that you just have to stop and have a bite. The restaurant is really, really small, seriously. If you have a part of 5 or more, like I did, be ready to wait for an hour or more, especially at dinner time. So keep that in mind. What I saw was a lot of take outs, which is something that I will do next time, instead of dining in and waiting forever. They just don't have the space, and they don't take reservations or call aheads. Other than that, the staff and hostess were great and friendly. The pizza is done right inside brick oven. I believe one pizza would feed two, but if you're really hungry, then just stick with one all for yourself. The price is decent, compared to other NYC restaurants.

review_data.review: This place was recommended highly by other trip advisor writers, so we tried it and we were not disappointed. It fed 2 people for 2 nights. We also noted that there is construction next door therefore parking is harder than usual. Order online or on the phone and go pick it up. They have seedy rolls to die for.

review_data.review: We walked to the place and ordered. All of the selections looked good so we had a battered fish taco and pork and chicken tacos. The beers are 9$NZD so we passed those up. It was pretty cold and rainy out the nite we came so we did not eat at the tables outside.

review_data.review_title: The best food I have ever tasted
review_data.review: We visited on a Sunday evening and selected the Chef's Tasting menu with wine pairing. Every single morsel that I placed in my mouth was sensational. I hunt and butcher my own venison, so I have eaten a lot, but what I was served that night was the best that I have ever had. I am salivating again thinking about the chicken liver parfait and the turbot. And how does one make celeriac taste that good? It's a lovely cosy place and the staff were all really pleasant (That sounds like damning with faint praise. They were great!). All in all, a memorable experience.

user_data.user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;Luxury Traveler

review_data.review: Superb meal. Lots of tasty small plates. Highly recommend the baked reblouchon. We tried to many different wines. What a treat. Best meal in Prague.

user_data.user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;Luxury Traveler

review_data.review: Having stayed at Le Bristol (and dined at 114) on a number of occasions, they introduced a vegetarian menu following some feedback during a previous stay. At Christmas, I’d seen significant improvements overall, providing some further feedback on the mains specifically (see previous review). With an unexpected return visit in March, I looked forward to my dining experience.  The amuse bouche of scrambled eggs black truffle and chives was excellent. The starter - a mesclun truffle salad - lacked finesse (noting I later discovered this had been updated on the main menu but not the vegetarian menu, which still had it as a signature dish in the ~ 40 euro mark when in fact it had been replaced by a basic lettuce leaf salad with a small amount of grated truffle). See photos. As per my previous visit, the mains were still uninspiring and frankly a lazy selection of basic vegetables – noting the morels were extremely salty. The mille-feuille dessert was very enjoyable.  Service was inattentive – 15 minute waits were frequent for clearing plates, asking for the sommelier to their arrival, etc.  On advising the Maître d' of my initial disappointment with the starter, and on providing feedback on the experience as a whole, he was very professional. And assured me the feedback would be noted.  As Hotel Le Bristol prides itself on being a level above most hotels, and commands a premium for such, I sincerely hope improvements are made.  Note – I appreciate France is not renowned for being vegetarian friendly, however as a restaurant attached to a premium hotel catering for largely international guests, expect better.

For a quick and casual meal at Atlantis, we headed to The Edge. This outdoor bistro/bar offers a range of super tasty meals and a wonderful service. user_data.user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;Luxury Traveler

review_data.review: Over the years I’ve come to expect Mlýnec to deliver a very good festival menu, which is why this restaurant was the fourth and last round with my Danish friends before they headed back home. It is safe to say that the restaurant didn’t disappoint. We were all blown away by the experience. We were greeted by the manager (I believe) and sat down at a nice table. The interior of the restaurant has been redone, and we liked it. Particularly we liked the acoustics of the room. Noise doesn’t travel from table to table, and we could have a relaxed conversation without raising our voices or listening in on whatever was being discussed by the table next to ours. We had a bowl of bread with 3 different kinds of fresh and slightly warm bread. It was accompanied by a herb spread which had nice, subtle flavours and a perfect temperature. I wanted more bread! But thank God they didn’t give me any (I didn't ask for it), because we were all completely full, when we left the restaurant a couple of hours later. The amuse bouche was delicate foam of smoked potatoes. There were some crunchy bits on top and a bit of sour notes from tiny pieces of pickled vegetables as well. These 2 elements gave some texture, and it was a brilliant little dish. The starter was smoked char with almond milk “caviar”, beluga lentils, horseradish, and marjoram. The trout had a firm, yet tender texture and had received just the right amount of smoke. The subtle horseradish sauce with marjoram complimented both fish and lentils very well and made everything come together. The lentils were perfectly cooked – I am not sure if “al dente” is a way to describe lentils, but I’ll risk it. The almond milk caviar was mainly on the plate for texture, I believe – it didn’t pack a lot of flavour. I like that the “eggs” had different sizes. That worked well visually and also when it came to the texture. The size of the portion was generous – we all agreed that it wouldn’t have been strange at all, if they had served one piece of trout instead of the two nice portions on our plates. The main dish was veal rib eye, beans, dried beef, beets, cashews, and demi glace. We were given a choice how we would like our meat prepared, and we all chose medium. Mine was closer to medium rare, and that was perfectly fine with me. The first impression of the dish came from tasting the demi glace, which was one of the best I’ve ever had. Only the master of sauces, Steven Trumpfheller, has served me a better one. So rich and full of flavour and reduced to the point where it would make my lips stick together. The steak was tender and well seasoned, and it hade more and deeper flavour than I would have expected from veal – more like a young bull. There were 3 different types of beans on the side, all cooked to perfection. The beets added an earthy and sweet/sour dimension, and the small bites of smoked and dried beef held it together, although my first bite was very tough (the rest weren’t). Just as it was the case with the starter, everything on the plate created a perfect combination, and the dish was quite filling. I regretted not having saved a slice of bread to wipe my plate clean with. Not to embarrass my two friends at the table I decided not to lick the sauce off my plate, but the thought crossed my mind. The dessert was macaroon in two ways, cherry, chocolate, tangerine, and basil garnished with raspberries and a blackberry. The macaroon on the side was good, but to me the star of the dish was the clever composition in the middle. I tried tasting the different elements individually, and they went almost all the way around the palate, except for saltiness. Sweet, sour, tart, bitter. And then when they all met in combination with the chewy and a little bit gooey macaroon bottom, it was simply a heavenly mouthful. The menu mentions a pre-dessert as a palate cleanser. Previously it has been a ball of sorbet. They forgot to serve it at our table, but they found out and insisted that we had coffee on the house, accompanied with cute cubes of chocolaty caramel. It was a nice finish to our meal. The service was friendly and attentive, and we were given plenty of time between dishes, which we really appreciate. We were served by different waiters, but the manager always kept an eye on our table and checked every once in a while if we were happy – and it was a pleasure chatting with him. Hospitality must lie in his genes. We agreed that this final festival experience was a perfect ending to this year’s adventure as a group – and most definitely we’re looking forward to repeating it next year! There are 2 seats left for the Restaurant festival at Mlýnec this year: 1 seat on the 12/2 at 17:30 and 1 on the 16/2 at 17:30. Grab them!

review_data.review: I've been curious for a long time how good the brunch at Mlýnec is? It's served on Saturdays and Sundays between 11:30-15:00. The menu changes from week to week. The price is Czk. 1.290, - per person. It includes prosecco, red wine, white wine, beer, coffee, freshly squeezed orange juice and other soft drinks ad libitum. My boss, who is pretty awesome - and has asked me out several times this week - is in Prague with her husband, and I thought it appropriate to ask them out, just once. We usually attend the Grand Restaurant Festival together, but that’s not an option this year. Instead we’ve designed our own culinary week. The menu we had yesterday is below. Food is served at the table. We were given dishes to share, and we were pleased with the portion sizes, which allowed us to taste everything. By the time we had done that, we were also absolutely stuffed. Everything we were served was impressively delicious. The praise came in a stream from all three of us. We were impressed with the quality of the prosecco and wines included in what was effectively an all-you-can-drink package. The service was also absolutely perfect. The team of waiters were quite young and they were well trained in the profession, they were polite, friendly, helpful and had both humour and the courage to bring their personalities to work. When we arrived at 11:30, we discussed whether we could have arrived a little later and still had plenty of time before 15:00. But the service was kind enough to give us plenty of time between courses, we had a good time - and by 14:35 we were ready for dessert, which by the way was a feast of flavours and textures and one of the many highlights of the brunch. We'll be back!  STARTERS Codfish ceviche, shallot, dill Veal tataki, wasabi mayonnaise Beetroot carpaccio, goat cheese, black rice  MAIN DISHES Salmon trout, tabouleh salad, miso, tapioca Pork tenderloin, Guinea-fowl breast, parmesan cheese, herbs, albufera sauce Baked pumpkin, cauliflower, parsley, Brussel sprouts, almond, sweet potato croquete, gruyére cheese, aioli mayonnaise  DESSERTS Pistachio cheesecake, raspberries, chocolate Coconut, almonds, turmeric, vanilla  WINES Prosecco Riondo, extra dry, Veneto White wine: Pinot Grigio , Casalforte, Veneto Red wine: Valpolicella , Casalforte, Veneto

A very small restaurant within a short distance to the Place Jemaa El Fena. It is not easy to find inspite on the mail road. It opens at 1.00pm and closes 10.00pm. It is closed on Wednesday. There were two small tables on the ground floor with the main open kitchen behind them. On the first floor there were10 small tables for 4 people each.  Be prepared to wait a while as the food is freshly prepared. It is worth the wait as the food is delicious. I have been there on two occasions and on both time there was only one waitress who spoke very good English and was rushed off her feet. The local dish which I chose called Tajine was lovely. I chose a Tajine chicken which had fresh vegetables - runner beans, potatoes, carrots, olives (photo enclosed). This was my first Moroccan dish and I was not disappointed.  On the second time I had a freshly made pizza and it was just as enjoyable as the traditional Moroccan dish. Everything on it was fresh and it tasted wonderful. It tasted better than the ones that I had in Rome and Sicily.  This little restaurant gets very busy. I would highly recommend going early as possible otherwise there can be an hour waiting time. Diners do seem to be in a hurry to leave.  You will not be disappointed as it is a great place to enjoy home cooking at a very reasonable price.

review_data.review: I'm not surprised we got the last reservation for dinner though we booked it several days in advance and this is not tourist season. Word is out that they have good food.  My partner and I shared a prawn appetizer. Do Europeans think it's fun for customers to dismember whole prawns, eyeballs and all? It's not! I don't like having to work so hard to get to the edible bits in a restaurant. The prawn flesh was tasty and the lemony garlicky sauce was good enough to eat with a spoon (which I did).  We both ordered the grilled octopus that came with a few thin spears of broccolini and three small whole potatoes. The octopus was perfect. Tender and succulent, with delicious shavings of crispy garlic in the sauce.  We asked for tap water and were given filtered water and charged 1.50 euro. Not a lot but tap water is very drinkable in Lisbon and they should make it available for free.  To compliment the meal we each had a glass of tasty wine, not overpriced at 5 euro a glass.

I've recently been to the Woodspeen near Newbury and the Latymer at Penny Hill Park, but Launceston Place takes the top spot. We had the fresh spring rolls and the pomelo salad, the outstanding beef loc lac, fish soup, and chicken Khmer curry. We had three traditional Cambodian desserts. The loc lac was amazing! Amazing! The Khmer curry was the absolute best of all the places we dined at in Siem Reap. Honestly and truthfully, so amazing. As a matter of fact, while we were fine dining at the Embassy, we were contemplating heading over to Haven after to scoop up a heartier meal. The desserts were delicious and like written online, were not sweet, swimming in coconut milk, and served hot. Everything was a winner and the chef was able to make the fried calamari gluten-free as well.  Danke Schoen for the best meal. So looking forward to dining at Haven on our next visit.  Notes: al fresco dining and not a mosquito in sight.  $65 USD

user_data.user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;Luxury Traveler

review_data.review_title: Great Service, Average Food, Fantastic Juices!
review_data.review: We dined here for dinner on our first evening in Siem Reap. Unfortunately, the dish wrapped in bacon, the main course, was way overcooked. The meat was tough. Very tasty though. The juices were the most enjoyable part of the dining experience, oh, and the gluten-free coconut ice cream.  Overall, decent. Really bummed to have not had the outstanding experience that others had. Maybe we were just too early and the kitchen wasn't prepared. Bummer.

I arrived there for a dinner with a friend, and there was nobody to welcome us and take us to the table where we have to sit... a busy guy showed up suddenly and gave us the table. The staff members were so busy doing nothing I guess, because there was only 3 other tables with customers. After 10 minutes of searching to whom I should give my order, a gentleman showed up and took the order. I ordered 3 main dishes and 1 nan and 1 rooti... the waiter didn’t give me any advices with the bread amount, as 2 bread is fine for me, but not in Gazebo... the bread size is quarter to the regular size of the bread, yes! Maybe less that the quarter! When I saw the bread, I ordered more and it took forever to arrive. Also, I asked the waiter to bring me corn snacks (papad) and he asked me, how many pieces? It was my first time to be asked how many pieces I need... because they bring it with the starter, and regardless the level of the restaurant, they bring 5-6 pieces... but I ordered 4... and till now it didn’t come... it never came... I told the waiter about it when I was leaving... and he simply forgot... food was good and below the very good, the price is very good to compare it with the food quality.

user_data.user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;Luxury Traveler

review_data.review: We were staying in a nearby hotel and used our TripAdvisor community to find a good restaurant. As usual, the reviews were spot on. This was a gem that deserves it's high rank. We had well made cocktails, and were served some complimentary soup before our appetizers came. Both our meals were delicious, and the service was spot on. There's a lovely ambiance to the place that was only marred by the fool at the next table talking on his cell phone, but definitely a nice date night place. One of our best meals of the trip, and I'm a fussy Italian cook. Not inexpensive but worth the splurge.

user_data.user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;Luxury Traveler

review_data.review: We booked to go here on a whim on Christmas Day. The restaurant is huge, it was busy but not full occupancy. Reassuringly we thought, it was extremely popular with the Indian community so we were anticipating an enjoyable dining experience. Unfortunately this was not the case. My chosen starter wasn't noted as being hot and spicy, but for my palate it was and it spoilt what could have been a nice starter. The portion size of the first course was huge, and could have warranted for being half the size. Our choice of mains, although different I thought tasted very much the same. The chicken was a little chewy and we just couldn't get excited about it. The service was also just ok, not very personal and not very engaging.  We've eaten all over the world on our travels, so I fully understand how Indian food can differ. But, let's just say, if we go back to NYC we'll be swerving Utsav.

review_data.review_title: Excellent Afternoon Tea In a lovely environment and outstanding service.
review_data.review: Despite London having moved into the new Tier 2 (High) Covid-19 category, my wife and myself had Afternoon Tea earlier today in the Park Room at the Grosvenor House Hotel on Park Lane.  We arrived a little late but were given a warm welcome by both Andre and Herlyn who were not only expecting us (current bookings are understandably much lower than normal) but provided exceptional service throughout our visit. With only one other table taken, we were soon sitting at one of the nice window tables overlooking Hyde Park.  After taking our Tea (we both opted for English Breakfast) and Jam (Ginger & Rhubarb, Rose Petal and Strawberry) orders, it wasn’t long before our substantial Afternoon Tea (good range of delicious sandwiches, 4 lovely scones and some nice deserts) arrived. There was certainly plenty to eat and what was left was put into a doggy bag together with 2 slices of lemon drizzle cake.  Not only that, we had two pots of Ginger & Lemon Tea before departing by which time it was pleasing to see several other tables having been taken.  All in all, it was a most enjoyable experience - enhanced by both Andre & Herlyn who certainly went the extra mile as far as we were concerned!

I visited this restaurant in june of this year Even though the sous chef had a problem they honor my reservation and the service was incredible this small place with limited seating (in my experience this has the advantage of more intimate meal and it forces the chef to make every dish special) the food is full of creativity and the tasting menu has the best quality price relation in paris. this is a well balanced menu and you don't end up hungry or excessively full.  The chef was super nice and when i wanted to know the name of and ingredient he tipped for me in my phone.  we tried to come back before leaving paris and it wasn't posible fully booked for the week so this restaurant is a new reason to comeback in 2018. i hope this restaurant continues to evolve and gain the recognition it deserves i can see a michelin star approaching

Paul and his wife ( owners) started this project in order to provide youth with an opportunity to acquire life, work and employment skills. Youth go through an internship process for a number of months. When they graduate they are hired at local high-end restaurants as they have excellent hospitality skills, knowledge abilities. user_data.user_tags: Art and Architecture Lover;Foodie;Like a Local;Luxury Traveler

review_data.review: This is another amazing social profit enterprise. They take in disadvantaged youth. They train, educate, coach and mentor young adults to be self-sustaining and employed in today’s world. They also run a 1st class restaurant with excellent food, ambience and incredible customer service. Thank You for what you do.

They take in disadvantaged youth - train them in life skills, work skills, hospitality management - being servers, cooks , chefs , managers etc. Then trainees are sent out to other hotels for internships and then after graduation they all find jobs in the local Siem Reap hospitality industry. A remarkable process. Train your staff well and they will look after your customers.

we always stop in and have dinner or lunch @ Tevy’s Place. Tevy and her staff are so welcoming. Excellent service and menu choices at a very reasonable price. I love this restaurant. The food was s 12/10 , interesting ambience, great staff and excellent customer service . If you sit a front you can watch them cook your meal. All female staff. This place is another social profit enterprise. Tevy supports educational programs for disadvantaged youth - specifically females in Siem Reap. She deserves the Order of Cambodia. Pucs to follow

simply an amazing restaurant. Here is another example of a social profit agency that works the restaurant business and puts $$$ back into the community. You just have to go there. The food, music, decor, ambience and customer service is Outstanding.

review_data.review_title: Authentic Turkish food off the beaten path
review_data.review: Massa Bistro Cafe & Restaurant is tucked away in an alley off of Dr. Eminpasa St. about 400m from Hagia Sophia. It is worth the extra effort to find, secluded from tourist hordes. I enjoyed dining in a quite & relaxing atmosphere after a long day of touring Istanbul. The owner greeted me, the staff was attentive, and explained menu choices. I ordered a grilled veggie plate, with eggplant, zucchini, tomatoes, pepper and onions. It came with french fries, rice and yogurt. Everything was freshly prepared, served hot, and perfectly spiced. Although the bistro has a bar, I did not order any alcoholic beverages, preferring to Turkish tea. Portions were generous, and prices were reasonable.

review_data.review_title: Great cocktails. Great fun. Great staff
review_data.review: With our stay at the Radisson Blu we received credit for the bar and restaurant, so we used ours in Be Bop bar.  Before I talk about the drinks, I want to talk about the staff. We sat at the bar for 3 nights, and on two nights were attended to by Honza (I hope that’s his name). Sure - you can just drink the drinks for theatre and get drunk and fall off your bar stool.  But what we learned over 3 nights is just how much time, energy, intelligence and creativity goes into the formulation of the recipes AND the ingredients that go into them. They make many of their own ingredients, and the processes take a long time and a lot of care and skill.  Now, to the cocktails.  They are unique, fun, beautifully balanced and well worth trying. I won’t say much about them, but if you want to sit at a bar, dressed in a laboratory coat and a safety mask, while a cocktail basically explodes in front of you, this is the place to go!  As well as their own list of house cocktails, they’ll make pretty much any cocktail you suggest.  BRILLIANT!

review_data.review_title: Absolutely terrible service - but decent food.
review_data.review: As someone that loves authentic Indian food and who has been to India over 40 times, I was looking forward to eating at Utsav. From the check-in with the hostess (who was very abrasive and curt) to when we got to the table, the service was absolutely horrendous. Waited 20 min for our order to be taken. 45 min until our first course arrived. The samosas were very tasty indeed, the squash soup was tasteless and the colic cauliflower was surprisingly tasty (that from colleague who dislikes cauliflower). Main course: the briani was ok; the lamb ragon josh was not curried enough(I asked for very spicy); the naan was bad enough that a true blooded Indian would not have touched it. The masala was ok but not curried enough; the vindaloo was good (but that is coming from a Texan who is used to Mac n cheese).  After we finished the main course we waited 25 min for the waiter to take away the dishes (after we called over the hostess). Another 20 min to order desert.  Desert was very lackluster, vanilla ice cream.  Overall decent food with the worst possible service.

review_data.review_title: What a waste of time and money
review_data.review: Jungsik was truly the worst Michelin starred restaurant I have ever been. We have started our night with dry greetings from the sommelier "We do not serve Korean drinks here sir, this is more of a French restaurant rather than Korean and our food is delicate". After tasting the seasonal menu I can confirm that it is bland not delicate. Tasteless, concept less, unimaginative food served in enormous portions. The big chunk of cod was murdered in a pepper sauce, the large layers of fat inside both pieces of lambs were probably there on purpose but definitely unappetising. Wine pairings with neither kicks nor soul. Mediocre deserts. Petit fours was only three. An unmemorable night you would want to forget, after digesting the amount in the credit card statement.

review_data.review: While spending a week in Phuket, we were looking for some good restaurants and we found some good reviews on the Dee Plee so we decided to give a try, knowing that Anantara is a very good and well recognized brand in Thailand.  The restaurant is located on the hills of the hotel, overlooking the hotel grounds, the sea and the beach. The decoration of the hotel is perfect, in Lanna style (northern thailand style) and the Lanna inspiration can be traced back in the menu... !  The menu is traditional thai with a number of plates from northern thailand (which is a different style from the south of thailand). Everything we ordered came in a very nice presentation and all the tastes were just amazing!! We had the possibility to have different type of rice, which is always great since Thailand has so much to offer on this front. The staff was super friendly and smiling and they contribute very significantly to the overall experience you have at Dee Plee. To me, Dee Plee is part of those restaurants who are truly honoring Thai food by offering to the guests a true culinary experience.  On thing to note, not so many restaurants in Thailand bring you the miang kham when you have dinner. Miang kham is actually the traditional thai snack that people enjoy when they are together. It consists of a bethel leave that you fill with roasted peanuts, coco, lime, shallots and some spicy paste. It is delicious and the perfect snack when you are having a beer or a glass of wine in Thailand but too few restaurants offer this.. I was really happy that Dee Plee has it.  All in all, we would certainly come back and highly recommend it!

review_data.review_title: Steak ! Steak! Did I mention steak?
review_data.review: Thoroughly enjoyed this adorable restaurant. Family of four.  We ordered two steaks and two salads - typically we have a gigantic appetite for steak and it was a huge amount of food - we suggest you SHARE STEAK AND ONE SALAD MAX PER FOUR PEOPLE.  If you are used to American Caesar salad we suggest passing on this, as their version wasn't what we are used to. Take a look at the other salads as they pass by - very large and deconstructed style. They offer half portions.  The decor of this restaurant was great with drawn on plates by past customers covering the walls and small air planes and toy blimps along the ceilings. It was filled with tourists but we didn't find it "too touristy".  The wait staff were very lovely and kind, spoke English very well.  Our only criticism would be that the food seemed to be rushed - the salad, steaks, and sides all came rushing to the table all at once very quickly overwhelming the table.  Would suggest this to our friends in the future !

review_data.review_title: Family or 'group' type of dining experience
review_data.review: First off warning about inability to find taxis on New Years Eve....UBER transportation suggested by hotel as taxi wait over 90minutes. UBER prices 6-7times higher rates than usual  Arrived on time at 930pm and greeted at bottom of staircase by server who spoke no English but gracious.  Upstairs we ascended to first floor and met other families and guests. Served bubbly wine and hung around WAITING for dinner for an hour. Tasty single appetizer offered for the hour.  1030pm Ascended another flight of stairs to warm/hot small room with basic tables and recorded music.  Served set menu (I believe they do offer vegetarian options) from Nicos' favourite winery I suspect. Not mine unfortunately.  Food was good as were wines - however AS FOODIE and lover of great wines would not have chosen this again as place to spend New Year's Eve. We were asked to use the same wine glasses from one tasting to the next - tacky. Home style cooking and presentation. Some dishes above average in taste - presentation average.  Desserts arrived as the clock struck 12 and we left shortly after.  While I would recommend this as REASONABLY priced wine/dine experience - and the food was good - I DON'T feel this listing deserves to rated number one dining location on TripAdvisor for BA.

review_data.review_title: Superb service, delicious food, and sublime experience at the Chef's tasting table
review_data.review: We stayed at the Park Hyatt for 3 nights during our trip to France. My birthday happened to fall during our stay and we tried to get a table online but the restaurant was showing as fully booked. We emailed the hotel and they were able to confirm a reservation for us just a few nights before. Imagine our surprise when we showed up for dinner and the wonderful maitre d' escorted us to the Chef's table! We did the 7 course tasting with wine pairing but we couldn't keep track of what number we were on, very quickly. (There were so many extras!) I have some dietary limitations which the chef was able to work around, seemingly easily. With the entire kitchen on show, it was a delightful experience though very intimate at the chef's table. We were already impressed and pleased with every course that came out but when the Wagyu beef course came out- I may have cried some tears of joy because it was perfection in my mouth. I even halted the chef to tell him how amazing it was in the middle of the course. Every pairing was a classic match to the dominant flavors of each dish. The cheese course was just ridiculous. In the sheer quantity and selection. Delicious but that quantity is rough on the stomach of non French diners. The madelines and after dinner pastry they offered to pack up to have the next morning (we were so full!) and we were thankful we did!!! Those madelines were better than any other madeline I had ever had and that snail shell was perfectly executed laminated dough.  We are no strangers to multi course fine dining in NYC. This is the classic French dining experience and this was executed perfectly.

review_data.review: Reading about this restaurant made me wanted to dine there , therefore we decided to go . A cheerful welcome was already a good sign . They seated us upstairs where we appreciated the decor all done around black red and white with an interesting illumination. The menu offers different choices from a degustation menu that involves also different wines from menu a la carte . We decided for a la carte and a bottle of Sancerre 2016 . But first We could not renounce to the temptation of tasting some beluga caviar which was excellent . The wine was excellent although it never reached the perfect temperature . My first course was bonito in tataki sauce which was delicious except for the chipped dish in which it was served . As a main course I choose a turbot with artichokes cooked in 3 ways, clams and a symphony of tastes that were exquisite . We were extremely pleased also with the perfect service and by meeting the creative chef .A place worth to return .

review_data.review: I am certainly Italian in my love of food! Dinner begins with focaccia, cherry tomato bruschetta brought unbidden to the table @Theo.Randall @icparklane. The cocktails are rife with strong Italian alcohols like Campari and vermouth, typical cocktails are Negronis and Old Fashioned. We tried both and they are well-fitting with the restaurant. It is impossible to choose one from Primi pasta dishes without regret that you have therefore missed another. When it’s pasta time, go for Taglierini con Gamberetti e Carciofi – a rich, overwhelmingly savoury mix of the freshest pasta with brown shrimps and artichokes. I usually don’t do this but we left our wine choices to the clued-up sommelier who really knew his stuff. In a tastefully decorated open-plan dining room that has plenty of space between the tables, he and his team offer a wide-ranging Italian menu with something for even the trickiest of eaters. Superb evening... flawless service and impeccable attention to detail. Yet another memorable night!

Место непроходное, поэтому тихо. Best place to eat in the center. Big portions, delicious, welcoming and warm service. Some complements from restaurant such as Turkish tea or coffe and some sweets or fruits.  Thank you! We will definitely come again.
